Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 04:27PM AllieM22 wrote: I was interested in see the response to this question as I had a lumpectomy in which the surgeon got clean margins on the initial tumor but while in there found another smaller tumor which he does need to go back and get clean margins on. This smaller (4mm) tumor also didn't show up on any tests (yikes). The oncologist is telling me I won't need chemo due to the fact that the tumor is grade 1, and highly hormone receptor positive (70%/10-%) and Her2 negative. So I'll just do radiation and tamoxifen. I am getting the Oncotype DX test just to be sure though. Anyone have a similar situation? (IDC, 1.8mm, stage 1, grade1, ER/PR+, HER2 -)
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and Negative Margins stang Route53

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 08:32PM AllieM22 wrote: I felt a lump a month after the reexcision surgery and had them ultrasound it and it was a cyst. I guess it did show up on the ultrasounds and MRI before but they didn't mention it b/c it was just a cyst. So I am confident that they have it right but will keep an eye on it... I guess if they are confident that you are ok but of course keep an eye on it. What did they say it was?
Posts.Title: Lump...Scar Tissue? Shirl runalot08

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 04:59PM AllieM22 wrote: I am having my first mammo next month, 6 mos after my last surgery and 3 months after the end of radiation--so we'll see!! Am a little nervous. Does anyone else still have some occasional soreness--I do sometimes if I bump myself or lay on it from a certain angle. I hope this will go away and is ok at this point...
Posts.Title: Would love to hear from anyone who has had rads with lumpectomy kdholt koshka1

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 01:44PM AllieM22 wrote: I was ok thru rads although wasn't working--and no kids to take care of! But I did take it easy and lay down when i needed to--also tried to walk at least a mile every day. I think that helped a lot. But everyone reacts differently. I did get some fatigue oddly enough a few weeks ago--it was like I was taking an antihistamine, you know where you feel sluggish and just want to go put your head down? I met with a nutritionist (separate from this issue) and she suggested that I get my folate, iron and B-12 levels tested, along with the vitamin D test she suggests for all cancer patients. So I will do that later this week. I did start taking an extra B complex vitamin along with a regular multiple. Seems to have helped a bit. She said not to take more iron or folates before the test but that a B complex was fine to add.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 09:39AM AllieM22 wrote: To answer the question on why the ultrasound before the boosts--it's to do a plan for the treatment-- to mark the area (usually the tumor cavity area) where they will do the boosts. That's what mine was anyway! :)
Posts.Title: I have a question ginnysue JulieC

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 09:12PM AllieM22 wrote: Hi Laney64--Good luck tomorrow. You will do great. The waiting is the hardest party--I heard that before mine and it's true. If the dr didn't mention a wire locator you may not need it and if you do, it's really not a big deal. They will numb you up. As you probably know, they do the SNB while you are under so you won't know any of that is going on. The dye insert beforehand does hurt (sorry) but it's really quick.  I figured that it was worth it so they can do the SNB vs just taking out all the lymph nodes like in the 'old days'. :) It will be over before you know it! Good luck!
Posts.Title: My lumpectomy is tomorrow Lainey64 AllieM22

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 05:31PM AllieM22 wrote: Twirlgirl- I LOVE the AntiCancer book. I read two other books specific to breast cancer before surgery on what to expect etc, but that was the first one I bought on general cancer. I thought it was so well written and appreciated all the information--especially on nutrition. I have passed it on to a number friends and family. My husband changed his diet when I did after reading that book and he has seen improvement in his cholesterol, weight and other blood #s already. Deanna-I am also interested in why I got cancer--as I have eaten well, exercised, etc. Of course my interest now is in how to prevent a recurrence so am glad people are talking about it here...
Posts.Title: Immune system problems and cancer related? ailenroc orange1

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 02:12AM AllieM22 wrote: Hi ladies-- some of you mentioned exercises to do. Can you explain? I went to see a PT to be proactive and she showed me how to do the lymph massage but no exercises. I did also get a sleeve to wear when I fly. I had 3 nodes removed but just want to be proactive so I do all I can to avoid it! :)
Posts.Title: I am flying this week,uh oh lymphedema? skigrl kira

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2008 11:43PM AllieM22 wrote: Hi Mary-- Glad you got some more info. Hope the antibiotics do the  trick--quickly! I had some proactive antibiotics after surgery so maybe that helped me. I just took off the steri strips on the SNB incision (since they were falling off) which looks pretty good. Am not taking off the ones on the breast yet--plus I have to go in to get clean margins next Wed so no need to take them off any sooner. The pain in my nipple is better and when I went in last week to meet with the radiologist, she felt around there and didn't feel anything so that made me feel better. Now I am looking forward to having surgery done with! :)
Posts.Title: Sore breast due to location of surgery?? goldendragonlady AllieM22

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 07:51PM AllieM22 wrote: Add me in--I had my lumpectomy on 10-15. Still a bit sore but feeling much better this week. I do have to go back for re-excision on 11-12--not looking forward to that but at least I know what to expect so that lessens the anxiety and then (hopefully) I'll be all done with surgery! I didn't need pain meds either after surgery although it's still sore a bit walking sometimes or if the seat belt hits the area. Wish I had had something before the SNB injections (ouch!) or the wire insertion although the wire wasn't bad (had the numbing shots) but I had it sitting up while in the mammogram "squeeze" so made me a bit woozy although that was probably lack of food and water the night before... KLP--how did they give you the Valium?
Posts.Title: Surgery's over, Now what? Firni lktracey

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 11:37PM AllieM22 wrote: I am so interested in your post b/c I have the same thing going on! My lumpectomy was actually two spots--one at 9:00 (1.5cm) and the other small one the surgeon found when he was in there and removed. That one is at like 8:00 I think and closer to the skin. The first week out of surgery it really didn't hurt that much at all but this last week (2 weeks out of surgery) the nipple has been off and on really sensitive and sore. My scar is horizontally out from the nipple but up to it. I would be interested if anyone has had this experience--I hope it is healing under there. I need to go in for re-excision surgery next week to get better margins on the small 'surprise' one (4mm) so I guess they would see if anything was awry in there at that time...let me know what you hear on Fri....
Posts.Title: Sore breast due to location of surgery?? goldendragonlady AllieM22

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 07:25PM AllieM22 wrote: I didn't need the wire locator for the tumor as it was palpable but did for a small lump which actually tested benign (biopsy) but we decided should come out too. I did have general anesthesia but I don't think a heavy dose of it. Only had lidocaine for the wire locator which was ok except they had to do it with mammogram which was a little involved. I did however stay over at the hospital for one night--just to be precautious. Their suggestion so I took them up on it being really worn out I think from not eating and drinking at like 6:00 the night before. Just some slight discomfort--I didn't take any of the meds as didn't need them, although I think having someone to help is a really good idea (esp with kids) since you aren't supposed to reach with that arm too much at first and no lifting of anything. My husband stayed home from work for a few days and it was nice to have him cook and go to the store. I was just a little more tired than usual so napped and lounged around, but it probably depends on each person and what they did. They took out 2 lumps for me and did the SNB (with the nuclear injection). You should rest though and let your body recover from the surgery. I have read input from other women who went right back to work and regretted it. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - What to expect? EleanorJ koshka1
